titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to William J. Jedlick. Papers, 1967-1987.
titlestmt.author: Pamela Cooley

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid created with EADitor by user nycoofam.
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: This collection contains a rough draft and final copy of Jedlick's 1967 Masters Thesis, "Landscape Window Shades of the 19th Century in New York and New England" for the Cooperstown Graduate Program, Cooperstown, NY; a 22 page booklet entitled, Shades of History; and material related to the thesis and booklet. It also of correspondence, b&w and color photographs, publications and related material in which Jedlick is credited for his scholarship and photography.

processinfo.p: The processing, cataloging, and encoding of this collection were made possible by a grant from the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Theses J349 "Landscape window shades of the 19th century on New York State and New England," by William J. Jedlick.
747.5 L479 "Shades of History," by Ruth Lee.

accessrestrict.p: Coll. No. 448 collection is open for research according to the regulations of Fenimore Art Museum Library.

bioghist.p: Jedlick’s avid interest in painted window shades of the 19th century arose in 1967 from his search for a research topic while a student at the Cooperstown Graduate Program, Cooperstown, NY. His resulting Masters Thesis, "Landscape Window Shades of the 19th Century in New York and New England," started him on a trail of discovery that he pursued into the 1980s as he researched, consulted on, photographed, collected, appraised, and dealt in painted window shades, and lent them to museums for exhibition.
bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: In 1968-1969, he consulted with Ruth Lee, Publicity Director for Joanna Western Mills, Co., Chicago, Illinois, on her 22 page booklet, Shades of History. Around that same time, Jedlick served as Associate Curator and Assistant Director of the Chicago Historical Society, and from about 1974-1987 as Regional Museum Curator for the National Park Service, N. E. Region, Philadelphia, PA. In 1987, Jedlick was also appraising antiques for W.J. Jedlick Appraisers, Philadelphia, PA. His first Masters Thesis, written while a student at DePaul University, Chicago, IL, in 1953, was entitled “Letters of Morris Sleight on the California Trail, 1850.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains a rough draft and final copy of Jedlick's 1967 Masters Thesis, "Landscape Window Shades of the 19th Century in New York and New England" for the Cooperstown Graduate Program, Cooperstown, NY; a 22 page booklet entitled, Shades of History; and material related to the thesis and booklet.
scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: It also contains correspondence requesting information about shades from Jedlick, and documenting Jedlick’s activity collecting, lending, donating, and selling window shades. Numerous b&w and color photographs (many of them labeled) in various formats, primarily of painted screens and building exteriors and interiors; and three publications and related material in which Jedlick is credited for his scholarship and photography are included. Finally, Jedlick's student papers on both Grecian and Hudson River School painting, 1967, and speeches on "The Past is Prologue to the Future" given at the Lake Forest (IL) Antique Show Press Luncheon, 1970, and on the publication release of Shades of History can be found in this collection.

userestrict.p: The copyright law of the United States (Title 17, United States Code) governs the making of photocopies or other reproductions of copyrighted material.
